title: Detection of the CD8+T cell immune response in mice infected with OVA-Listeria monocytogenes
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Part one: Preparation of OVA-Listeria monocytogenes and tail vein injection in mice
Timing: 16–18 h
This section details how to prepare OVA-Listeria monocytogenes and perform tail vein injection.
Note: The previous data determined the relationship between time, OD600 and bacterial concentration. After 12 h of activation, the Listeria monocytogenes was transferred. The OD600 was measured to be 0.35 after 2.5 h of transfer, and the concentration of Listeria monocytogenes in the bacterial solution was 8.4 × 107 CFU/mL. The bacterial injection per mouse was 1.25 × 107 CFU. A total of 150 μL of bacterial solution with OD600 = 3.5 was required for each mouse.
Preparation of OVA-Listeria monocytogenes.
Add 10 μL bacterial solution (frozen at −80°C) to 2 mL BHI medium containing erythromycin. Incubate in a shaker at 220 rpm/min for 12 h at 37°C.
Add 20 μL activated bacterial solution to 2 mL BHI medium containing erythromycin. Incubate in a shaker at 220 rpm/min for 2.5 h at 37°C.
Note: If more mice need to be injected, the culture system can be scaled up. The culture volume used here was 2 mL.
Critical: After 2.5 h of bacterial transfer culture, the logarithmic growth phase was reached, and the growth rate of Listeria monocytogenes was very fast. The incubation time needs to be strictly controlled. It should be stopped immediately after 2.5 h.
Collect the bacterial solution into 1.5 EP tubes, centrifuge at 2100 × g for 10 min at 4°C, discard the supernatant.
Add 1 mL of PBS to resuspend Listeria monocytogenes, centrifuge at 2100 × g for 10 min at 4°C, discard the supernatant.
Repeat step d. three times.
Resuspend the bacterial solution in PBS to a concentration of 1.25 × 108 CFU/mL.
Tail vein injection.

Immobilization of the mouse with a mouse immobilizer.
Wipe the mouse tail with an alcohol swab to make the veins more visible.
Inject 100 μL of bacterial suspension into mice from the tail vein with a syringe.
Critical: When injecting into the tail vein of mice, be careful not to make mistakes and apply pressure to the wound with cotton after withdrawing the syringe to avoid fluid leakage.
Keep the mice with free access to water and food after the injection of OVA-Listeria monocytogenes. Observe the mouse’s status every day.
Part two: Detection of bacterial load in the liver (on day 7 after infection)
Timing: 3–5 h
This section details the detection of mouse liver bacterial load. Includes liver processing, extraction, and quantification of OVA-Listeria monocytogenes.
Note: This experimental result reflects the ability of CD8+ T cells to clear OVA-Listeria monocytogenes in mice.
Prepare BHI plates in advance, preheat and dry them in a 37°C incubator for 1 h.
Preparation of Liver Tissue Grinding Suspension.
Prepare and label homogenization bags.
Remove and weigh the whole livers from mice. Place the whole liver into a homogenization bag.
Seal the homogenization bag and use a cylindrical tool to roll the surface of the homogenization bag to thoroughly homogenize the liver.
Add 5 mL of PBS.
Filter through a 70 μm sieve.
Diluted liver suspension.
Transfer 200 μL of liver suspension to a 96-well plate.
Perform 1:10 serial dilutions of liver suspension in PBS to 10−5 dilution within the wells of the 96-well plate.
Spread Liver Suspension.
Spread 100 μL of each dilution onto a predried BHI plate using a spreader. Incubate plates at 37°C for 12 h.
Count the number of CFU for each dilution, and calculate the CFU per tissue (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).

Critical: Be careful to grind the liver thoroughly and mix well before diluting the liver suspension.
Critical: Make sure the BHI plate is dry before coating it. Additionally, ensure that it is completely dry before finishing the coating process. Two control samples need to be set up. The first control is the coating plate of liver suspension from uninjected mice to rule out non-specificity and cross-contamination. The second control is the coating plate of the serially diluted suspension of known OVA-Listeria monocytogenes quantity to ensure the quality control of the agar plate.
Part three: Detection of OVA-specific CD8+ T cells in the spleen (on day 7 after infection)
Timing: 4–6 h
This section details the detection of OVA-specific CD8+ T-cell immune responses in mice.
Prepare mouse splenocytes.
Remove the whole spleens from mice.
Cut the whole spleen in half with scissors and place on a 40 μm sieve.
House the sieve in a 50 mL centrifuge tube. Wet the mesh and tissue with 0.2% BSA PBS.
Grind the tissue gently to dissociate cells with the core of a 2.5 mL syringe. Add 0.2% BSA PBS buffer while grinding.
Centrifugation at 400 × g for 5 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C), and discard the supernatant.
Lyse red blood cells.

Add 2 mL erythrocyte lysate and gently resuspend the cells by pipetting up and down. Let stand at room temperature (20°C–25°C) for 2 min.
Add 8 mL 0.2% BSA PBS buffer. Centrifugation at 400 × g for 5 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C), and discard the supernatant.
Add 8 mL 0.2% BSA PBS buffer, repeat centrifugation as in step b.
Discard the supernatant and add 2 mL 0.2% BSA PBS buffer to resuspend the cells.
Cell count.
Count viable cells and adjust to 1 × 107 cells/mL with 0.2% BSA PBS buffer.
Distribute the cell suspension into 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tubes with 100 μL/tube (1×106 cells/tube).
Block Fc receptors.
Note: Fc receptors bind antibody-antigen immune complexes and mediate adaptive immune responses. TruStain FcX PLUS is specific to the common epitope of CD16/CD32. It is useful for blocking nonspecific binding of immunoglobulin to Fc receptors.
Add 0.5 μL TruStain FcX PLUS (anti-mouse CD16/32) Antibody to each sample tube.
Mix well by vortexing. Place on ice for 10 min.
Cell surface staining with PE H-2Kb OVA tetramer.
Add 10 μL H-2Kb OVA Tetramer-PE to each test tube and mixed well.
Incubate for 1 h at room temperature (20°C–25°C) in the dark.
Cell surface staining with FITC anti-mouse CD8 and PE/Cy7 anti-mouse CD44 antibodies.
Note: CD44 is a marker of T-cell activation.4[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4] Colabeling of mouse spleen cells with CD8 antibody and CD44 antibody enables precise analysis of OVA-specific CD8+ T cells.
Add 0.625 μL FITC anti-mouse CD8 antibody and 1.25 μL PE/Cy7 anti-mouse CD44 antibody to each test tube and mixed well. Incubate for 20 min on ice in the dark.
Add 1.5 mL 0.2% BSA PBS buffer, and centrifuge at 400 × g for 5 min. Discard the supernatant carefully.
Repeat step b twice.

Suspend the cells in 500 μL of 0.2% BSA PBS buffer.
Resuspend cell pellet in 0.5 mL of 0.2% BSA PBS buffer and add 5 μL of 7-AAD per million cells and incubate for 5–10 min in the dark before analysis.
Perform flow cytometric analysis. Representative data and a gating strategy are shown in (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).

Figure 3. OVA-specific CD8+ T cells from the spleen before and after OVA-Listeria monocytogenes infection
Spleens were harvested from OVA-Listeria monocytogenes-infected and uninfected mice at 7 days post-infection. A single-cell suspension was prepared and stained with anti-mouse CD8-FITC, CD44-PE/Cy7 antibody and OVA-Tetramer-PE.
(A) Gating strategy for OVA-specific CD8+ T cells in mouse spleens.
(B) Representative flow cytometry plots (left) and percentages (right) of OVA-specific CD8+ T cells from the spleen before and after OVA-Listeria monocytogenes infection. Data are representative of three independent experiments (B). Unpaired t test for the measurements between the two groups(B):∗∗p < 0.01.
Note: If the samples cannot be analyzed in time after processing, they can be stored at 4°C–8°C degrees in the dark but should not exceed 4 h.
Critical: Mouse cells are fragile, so dissociating mouse spleen cells needs to be gentle and always moist.
Critical: When lysing mouse spleen erythrocytes with erythrocyte lysing solution, it is important to strictly control the time and not exceed the recommended duration. This is to avoid any potential damage to other cells present in the sample.
Part four: Detection of functional subsets of spleen T cells (on day 7 after infection)
Timing: 8–10 h
This section describes the detection of functional T-cell immune responses in mice. Here, we assessed the function of T cells by detecting the expression of intracellular IFNγ, GzmB, TNFα and IL2.

Note: The sample preparation steps are the same as steps 7, 8, and 9 in Part three.
Prepare mouse splenocytes.
    The operation is the same as Step 7 in Part three.
Lyse red blood cells.
    The operation is the same as Step 8 in Part three.
Cell count
    The operation is the same as Step 9 in Part three.
Cell Activation
Aspirate a total of 1×106 cells and centrifuge at 400 × g for 5 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C) to remove the supernatant.
Add 200 μL of 1640 medium to resuspend the cells, and then add them to 96-well plates.
Add 0.4 μL of Cell Activation Cocktail (with Brefeldin A) to each well.
The cells were incubated at 37°C in a CO2 incubator for 4 h.
Critical: The Cell Activation Cocktail stimulates cells for between 4–6 h. Do not exceed 6 h.
Block Fc receptors.
Harvest the activated cells and centrifuge them at 400 × g for 5 min. Discard the supernatant.
Add 1.5 mL of PBS buffer to the cell pellet, mix by vortexing or pipetting.
Centrifuge the harvested activated cells at 400 × g for 5 min. Discard the supernatant.
Resuspend cells in diluted 100 μL Zombie NIR solution.
Incubate the cells at room temperature (20°C–25°C), in the dark, for 30 min.
Add 1.5 mL of 0.2% BSA PBS buffer to the cell pellet, mix by vortexing or pipetting.
Centrifuge the sample at 400 × g for 5 min. Discard the supernatant.
Repeat step f and g.
Resuspend cells in 100 μL of 0.2% BSA PBS buffer.
Add 0.5 μL TruStain FcX PLUS (anti-mouse CD16/32) Antibody to each sample tube and mix well. Incubate on ice for 10 min.
Cell surface staining with APC anti-mouse CD8, Alexa Fluor 488 anti-mouse CD4 and BV510 anti-mouse CD44 antibodies.

Add 1.25 μL of APC anti-mouse CD8, 0.12 μL of Alexa Fluor 488 anti-mouse CD4 and 2.5 μL of BV510 anti-mouse CD44 antibody to each sample tube. Mix well. Incubate on ice for 20 min in the dark.
Add 1 mL 0.2% BSA PBS buffer and centrifuge at 400 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Discard the supernatant carefully. Vortex the tube and resuspend the cell pellet with the residual liquid.
Critical: When staining with Zombie NIR, it is important to ensure that the PBS used does not contain any other proteins such as BSA or FBS.
Critical: Please vortex thoroughly to ensure uniform mixing of the cells and to prevent uneven fixation in later stages.
Intracellular staining with PE/Cy7 anti-mouse IFNγ, PE anti-mouse GzmB, BV421 anti-mouse TNFα, PerCP/Cy5.5 anti-mouse IL2.
Dilute 10× Intracellular Staining Perm Wash Buffer to 1× in DI water.
Fix the cells in 0.5 mL/tube fixation buffer in the dark for 20 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Centrifuge the sample at 400 × g for 5 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C). Discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the fixed cells in Intracellular Staining Perm Wash Buffer and centrifuge at 400 × g for 5 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Repeat step d twice.
Resuspend fixed/permeabilized cells in 100 μL of intracellular staining Perm wash buffer.
Add 5 μL of PE/Cy7 anti-mouse IFN-γ, 5 μL of PE anti-mouse GzmB, 1.25 μL of BV421 anti-mouse TNFα and 5 μL of PerCP/Cy5.5 anti-mouse IL2 to each sample tube and mixed well. Incubate for 20 min in the dark at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Wash twice with 1 mL of Intracellular Staining Perm Wash Buffer and centrifuge at 400 × g for 5 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Resuspend fixed and intracellularly labeled cells in 400 μL 0.2% BSA PBS buffer.

Analyze prepared samples using flow cytometry. Representative data and a gating strategy are shown in (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).

A single-cell suspension was prepared, stimulated with Cell Activation Cocktail (with Brefeldin A) for 4 h and stained with anti-mouse CD8-APC, CD4- Alexa Fluor 488, CD44-BV510, IFNγ-PE/Cy7, Gzmb-PE, TNFα-BV421 and IL2-PerCP/Cy5.5 antibodies.
(A) Gating strategy for IFNγ, Gzmb, TNFα and IL2 positive CD8+ T or CD4+ cells.
